node.text:
🔊 All last week, we shared content with you from the Coral Triangle — and now, we want to invite you to come behind-the-scenes of our conservation journey in Timor-Leste, a young nation whose enchanting waters are bursting with an incredible variety of life, where they are making responsible and sustainable ecotourism an ideal way for local communities to support themselves. 

Join @mitty, @paulnicklen, and @andy_mann in the rich marine ecosystem of Timor-Leste for an unforgettable encounter with the goliath of the ocean: the blue whale. 

Shot by @paulnicklen, @mitty, and @andy_mann on @sonyalpha.

#ShotOnSony #BeAlpha #SonyAlpha

node.title: Behind the Scenes: SeaLegacy’s Conservation Journey | Timor-Leste

node.text:
In the final episode of our 'The Bahamas 2019' series, the team spends some time with the locals — Bahamians whose lives and culture revolve around and are dependent on their relationship with the ocean. Yet, the marine ecosystems in The Bahamas remain under constant threat of increased pollution, coastal development, unsustainable fishing practices, and the ever compounding effects of climate change. 

Our team's unforgettable experiences in The Bahamas in the past continue to fuel our dedication to advocating and fighting for the ecosystem and communities here in the present.

⛵ Can't get enough behind-the-scenes action? Well, you're in luck — starting next week, tune in to our stories to see what it's like to be part of the crew aboard The #SeaLegacy1 as we continue to support the needs of Bahamians on the ground over the coming months. #TurningTheTide

***The footage from this series was captured on expedition in early 2019, in a pre-COVID and pre-Dorian world

@paulnicklen @mitty @andy_mann @samkretch @moorecharitable @trevor_bacon1 @ceibahamas

#OnlyOneOcean #Bahamas

node.text:
In today's episode, join the SeaLegacy team on their mission to document a flourishing coral reef as a baseline in The Bahamas.

See with your own eyes what a healthy Caribbean reef system should look like; these reefs and the diverse species inhabiting them, including endangered species, give us hope for the future — and illuminate the life and ecosystems under the sea that need protecting in glaring technicolor.

***The footage from this series was captured on expedition in early 2019, in a pre-COVID and pre-Dorian world

@paulnicklen @mitty @andy_mann @samkretch @moorecharitable @trevor_bacon1 @ceibahamas

#TurningTheTide #OnlyOneOcean #Bahamas

node.text:
After discovering coral damage, pollution, and a distinct lack of predators at some of the reefs in The Bahamas, the SeaLegacy team is starting to question if they will get to see any sharks at all on this expedition.

Watch to see if their luck changes at Mayaguana, one of the most remote places in The Bahamas, where @Andy_Mann hopes he can guide @PaulNicklen and @Mitty on their first encounter with his favorite shark species — the oceanic whitetip.

***The footage from this series was captured on expedition in early 2019, in a pre-COVID and pre-Dorian world

@samkretch @moorecharitable @trevor_bacon1 @ceibahamas @theislandschool 

#TurningTheTide #OnlyOneOcean #Bahamas #TeamShark

node.text:
“We have a 97% failure rate. People think we just show up and know exactly where the animals are… and that’s not how it is.” - @paulnicklen 

On today's behind-the-scenes blast from the past, @paulnicklen, @mitty, @andy_mann, and the team embark on a true on-the-ground exploratory expedition in The Bahamas where they make some disheartening discoveries on a remote reef. 

Part of our job as storytellers is documenting both the beauty and the threats facing our ocean. This type of exploration comes with both victories and struggles, but no matter what we find, there are lessons to be learned and work we can do to keep #TurningTheTide.

***The footage from this series was captured on expedition in early 2019, in a pre-COVID and pre-Dorian world

@samkretch @moorecharitable @trevor_bacon1 @ceibahamas

#TurningTheTide #OnlyOneOcean #Bahamas

node.text:
We want to take you back in time to an unforgettable SeaLegacy expedition to The Bahamas — a past journey that has inspired our dedication to this incredible country and its invaluable ecosystems. The experiences our team had in 2019 are part of the reason the #SeaLegacy1 crew is on the ground there now!

Starting today, we will be sharing our 'The Bahamas 2019: Behind-the-Scenes' series with you. These never-before-seen SeaLegacy Diaries feature white-tip shark encounters with @andy_mann, blue hole filming challenges with @paulnicklen, endangered coral reef discoveries with @mitty, and more. Stay tuned all week — you won't want to miss any of it! 

***The footage from this series was captured on expedition in early 2019, in a pre-COVID and pre-Dorian world

@paulnicklen @mitty @andy_mann @samkretch @moorecharitable @trevor_bacon1 @ceibahamas

#TurningTheTide #OnlyOneOcean #Bahamas

node.text:
Despite pledges by the Ecuadorian government to protect Galápagos, a World Heritage Site and refuge for 3,000 marine species, industrial and unsustainable fishing practices are plundering its waters, devastating this delicate ecosystem. 

We’re calling on Ecuadorian President Lenín Moreno @leninmorenog and President of the National Assembly @cesarlitardo to fulfill their commitment to protect Galápagos and urgently expand the Galápagos Marine Reserve. Please show your support by signing the petition at only.one/galapagos (link in our story) and share!

#masgalapagos #yoestoycongalapagos #galapagos #ecuador

A pesar de las promesas del gobierno ecuatoriano de proteger Galápagos, Patrimonio Mundial y refugio de 3,000 especies marinas, la pesca industrial e insostenible está saqueando sus aguas, devastando este delicado ecosistema. 

Hacemos un llamado al presidente ecuatoriano Lenín Moreno @leninmorenog y al presidente de la Asamblea Nacional @cesarlitardo para que cumplan su promesa de proteger Galápagos y amplíen la Reserva Marina de Galápagos. Muestra tu apoyo firmando la petición en only.one/galapagos (link en story) ¡y por favor comparte!
.
.
.

Special thanks to @dvfernandez and @luksth for narrating and @robertoochoahe for contributing footage to this video. 
.
.
@mission_blue @migramarnet @mas_galapagos2020

node.text:
This decade, we have an extraordinary opportunity to transform the ocean and world as we know it. It's going to take #AllHandsOnDeck to tackle the climate crisis and rebuild ocean life but we know we can do it with you by our side. 

The Tide is a community of more than 4,000 supporters giving what they can each month to help rebuild marine life together. Join The Tide this #GivingTuesday and your donation will be doubled! 

100% of your contributions will support ocean stories, solutions, and campaigns around the world to help create a healthy, abundant ocean. Each month, you’ll see your impact come to life in a personalized monthly report outlining the projects you are supporting. Head to our stories for the link to join today. 

#ProtectSpecies #RestoreHabitats #PreserveSpaces #StopPollution #ReformFisheries #TackleClimateChange

node.text:
URGENT! We need your help! The Bahamian government has granted a license for offshore oil drilling that could start as soon as December 2020.

This project risks devastating the way of life for this ocean nation. Just one accident, one spill, would have dire consequences for both marine systems in the region and for Bahamians who depend on the ocean for their economy, employment, food sources, recreation, and culture. 

Young Bahamian leaders are urging their Prime Minister,  @opmthebahamas, to stop the project, and they need our help. 

“We refuse to stand by while our islands are endangered. We are not an oil nation. We are an ocean nation. It’s our past, our present, and our future."

Together, we can help these young leaders, @alannahvellacott, @laurenaritchie, @catislandkita, and @natureboyniel, Stop Oil Drilling in the #Bahamas.

Head to our story for the link to sign @OnlyOne's petition and learn more at only.one/bahamas

node.title: Stop Oil Drilling in the Bahamas

node.text:
🔊 Please turn up your volume and join @PaulNicklen on a journey to witness the remarkable coastal wolves of British Columbia. // “I am really proud of our small but mighty @SeaLegacy team when I see them create powerful and impactful storytelling pieces. Please watch the entire film and let me know your thoughts. @SeaLegacy and our partners at @RaincoastConservation have a plan to end the commercial trophy hunting of wolves, bears, and wolverines in British Columbia’s Kitlope Conservancy permanently, but we need your help. Two very generous patrons have just confirmed they will donation-match half of the final $100,000 needed to buy up the remaining hunting licenses in the area, which would double the impact of your contribution. A good friend of mine and avid supporter of @SeaLegacy just came in for $20K. Please visit the link in our bio if you want to get involved in pushing this protection over the finish line so we can save this community of wolves.” - @PaulNicklen 🙏💙 

Shot on assignment for @sealegacy with @johnkelseyphoto. Audio and BTS clips by @maxwelhohn, @steve_woods_photography, and @seaforthexpeditions. Edited by @chadrichmond 

#wolf #coastalwolf #bear #wolverine #kitlopeconservancy #BC #canada #fundraiser #conservation #donation #gratitude

node.text:
Threats to biodiversity are threats to all life on Earth. That includes us — human beings.

Because biodiversity IS life on Earth. 

Right now, one million plant and animal species are at risk of extinction. At @SeaLegacy, we are deeply concerned, but not defeated. 

If we can protect 30% of our lands, and 30% of our ocean by 2030 we can help reverse the loss of life around the globe. 

Please follow our friends at @ConservationOrg to stay up to date on their work.

node.text:
The secrets of the ocean are each of ours to hold and to protect. 

As a citizen of planet Earth, you were born into this story. 

Help us rewrite the future. 

Join @SeaLegacy, our co-founders @PaulNicklen, @Mitty, @ShawnHeinrichs and our friends at @OnlyOne for the launch of the platform set to change the course of ocean conservation and all life on this wild, beautiful planet — from the tiniest krill to the largest whale. 

There is @OnlyOne way to do this. 

Together. 💙

Get access today at the link in our bio.

node.text:
All @paulnicklen wants for his birthday is for our community to help him save the ocean. Click the link in our bio to join The Tide for Paul’s birthday tomorrow. When joining by 11:59 pm Eastern Time on July 25th you’ll also be entered to win Paul’s personal Super Sea Wolf 53 Zodiac watch. 

To the world, Paul is a celebrated artist known for constantly testing the limits of filmmaking and photography in order to inspire change. To us here at SeaLegacy, he is our fearless leader and dedicated team member. He’s made it his mission to keep us laughing, but he isn’t afraid to jump into the most important conversations of our generation- especially when they lead to action for the communities we work with and the future of our ocean. So whether you choose to join The Tide or enter the promotion, we hope you’ll celebrate with us and wish Paul a very happy birthday.

Visit the link in our bio and click on the photo matching this post! 

Photos by @paulnicklen 

#turningthetide #oceanconservation #humpbackwhales #polarbear 

Purchase/Contribution is not necessary to enter or win. Void where prohibited. Promotion ends July 25, 2021. Approx. value of prize package: $2,000.00. Subject to Official Rules on only.one/rules & restrictions on eligibility. Sponsor: Only One, 888 7th Ave, New York, NY 10106

node.text:
Visit the link in our bio and Join the Tide for @paulnicklen birthday this Wednesday. True to his nature, all Paul wants is for our followers to help him save the ocean. We hope you’ll celebrate with us by becoming part of The Tide - our community of passionate individuals helping to restore marine ecosystems across the world. You’ll also have the opportunity to win Paul’s very own Super Sea Wolf 53 Zodiac Watch- the watch that's been on the SeaLegacy 1 since the very start! Click the link in our bio to enter the promotion before 11:59 pm Eastern Time on July 25, 2021. All current Tide members are already entered.

Even as a child, @paulnicklen has always been deeply moved by the power and grace of our planet’s wildlife. He felt called to share his sense of awe for the natural world through his photography with a global audience - inspiring the kind of change that shapes entire generations. His work embodies the bond he shares with his animal subjects, and it’s this deep connection that has inspired millions to take action for the future of our seas.

Video by the SeaLegacy studios.

#turningthetide #sealegacystudios #oceanconservation #climatechange #thetide #entertowin

node.text:
Contrary to what most of us have learned about sharks, these secretive animals tend to be shy and cautious around people. Capturing this kind of close-up footage requires a practiced hand, patience, and an intuitive understanding of shark behavior. Luckily, @PaulNicklen has a gift for getting into the minds of just about every animal you can name. His filmmaking and photography depicting bears, wolves, and sharks have revealed our planet’s top predators as the complex and inquisitive beings they truly are. He sees the world through a lens of compassion, and his work has transformed millions of perspectives around the globe.⁠
⁠
This week, we hope you’ll help us wish Paul a very happy birthday by joining The Tide - our growing community of over 6,400 members furthering SeaLegacy’s conservation work. Paul has even agreed to part with his own Super Sea Wolf 53 Zodiac Watch and give it to one lucky winner. ⁠
⁠
Click the link in our bio to enter the promotion or join The Tide between 12 am Eastern Time on July 17 to 11:59 pm Eastern Time on July 25 to be eligible. All current Tide members are automatically entered.⁠
⁠
Video by @PaulNicklen⁠
⁠
#TurnTheTide #HappyBirthday #oceanconservation 

Purchase/Contribution is not necessary to enter or win. Void where prohibited. Promotion ends July 25, 2021. Approx. value of prize package: $2,000.00. Subject to Official Rules on only.one/giveaway-rules & restrictions on eligibility. Sponsor: Only One, 888 7th Ave, New York, NY 10106

node.text:
Tomorrow is the last day of #Sharkweek, and we want to let you know how grateful we are for your huge swell of support to stop the killing of endangered sharks in Costa Rica. Sign the petition at the link in our bio to add your voice.⁠
⁠
When we work together to raise our voices and demand change, we become a powerful force to be reckoned with! Speaking up on behalf of the wildlife that has no voice truly does make an impact. This week, more than 30,000 people sent a message to the government of Costa Rica, and it resonated loud and clear: President @carlosalvq must immediately restore critical protections for endangered sharks in Costa Rican waters! ⁠
⁠
Thank you once again for supporting the petition. Together we can #TurnTheTide! ⁠
⁠
Video by @Shawnheinrichs⁠
⁠
#Sharkweek2021 #sharks #oceanconservation #CostaRica

node.text:
Thank you to everyone who supported our campaign to save endangered sharks in Costa Rica over the past #SharkWeek. To keep the momentum going, please head to our link in bio and sign the petition. We are incredibly grateful to have a community of like-minded, passionate people working together to turn the tide for our oceans. More than 30,000 of you took a stand to tell the government of Costa Rica they must do better for sharks, and we encourage you to keep sharing the petition with your friends and family. We know we have shared some content recently which is difficult to watch, so for something a bit lighter here are some @Mitty photos of thriving, healthy sharks living their best lives! 

Sharks are ancient marvels of evolution who deserve respect and protection. Flourishing in our oceans for millions of years, their presence indicates a healthy marine ecosystem. As apex predators they are critical for the food web to function as nature intended. While sensationalized media often frames them as blood-thirsty killers, in reality they pose very little threat to humans. It’s the opposite, in fact. 

Humans have driven many species of sharks to the brink of extinction, mostly due to overfishing and exploitation. As many of you know, earlier this year Costa Rica’s government effectively legalized the overfishing of endangered sharks when they removed the ability of the Ministry of Environment to protect them. They shifted management responsibilities to the Institute of Fisheries and Aquaculture (INCOPESCA) – meaning sharks are no longer protected by Costa Rica’s Wildlife Conservation Law. 

If you haven’t yet signed the petition, head to the link in our bio to demand action from the government of Costa Rica to reverse this decision. You can also sign the petition by typing Only.one/costarica into your browser. 

Photos by @Mitty 

#sharks #ocean #conservation #turningthetide #sharkweek #sharkweek2021

node.text:
⚠️Warning: Graphic Content! Sign the petition at the link in our bio to stop the killing of sharks in Costa Rica, and please share it widely!

As heartbreaking as these images are, our role is to bring awareness to the tragic reality of what’s happening to sharks, and we deeply appreciate your support in driving change!

So, what happens to sharks after they’re hooked on longlines? They are either taken to port and sold in seafood markets under different names that hide the fact that they’re sharks, or their fins are sliced off and their bodies are callously dumped back into the ocean. The fins are then exported and used for shark fin soup – millions upon millions of sharks worldwide are killed for this reason. These intelligent, majestic creatures do not deserve this terrible fate, and it’s wiping them out.

The Costa Rican government removed the ability of the Ministry of Environment to protect sharks and shifted management responsibilities to the Institute of Fisheries and Aquaculture (INCOPESCA). The agency lacks the capacity to effectively monitor shark populations. In fact, they benefit from their commercialization.

Please, sign the petition today to demand action from the government of Costa Rica.

Photo by @shawnheinrichs 

#sharks #ocean #conservation #turningthetide #sharkweek #sharkweek2021

node.text:
⚠️ Warning: Graphic Content! Sign the petition at the link in our bio to stop the killing of sharks in Costa Rica. Costa Rica is using a legal loophole that allows that slaughter of sharks in its waters to continue unabated. Despite its image as an environmental leader, the government's apathy is causing an alarming decline in shark populations and several species are now on the brink of extinction. The fishing industry is absolutely decimating shark populations in Costa Rica and the government is allowing it to happen! 

Sign the petition at the link in our bio, stand with us and let the Costa Rican government know that its exploitation of sharks as a commercial species is unacceptable. Mr President Alvarado @carlosalvq you can stop this. 

Tag your friends in comments, reshare the posts. Let’s turn the tide together. 

Video by @shawnheinrichs 

#shark #ocean #conservation #turningthetide #sharkweek #sharkweek2021

node.text:
Sign the petition in our bio, and discover below the answer to one of your 🦈 questions. 

"What's the fastest shark in the world?" The Mako sharks are the fastest sharks in the ocean, slicing through the waves with sleek, streamlined bodies built for speed. Capable of swimming up to 60km hour, they are fierce and highly intelligent predators. Unfortunately, makos are also hunted for their fins and meat, which are highly valuable on international markets. Over the past few decades, mako shark populations across the globe have plummeted as a result of unregulated fishing and unchecked exploitation in longline fisheries. 

Instead of putting in the right measures to protect its wildlife, Costa Rica’s government removed earlier this year the ability of the Ministry of Environment to protect sharks, and shifted their management responsibilities to the Institute of Fisheries and Aquaculture (INCOPESCA). This single action basically legalised the overfishing of sharks. 

Sign the petition through the link in our bio and join the fight to stop the killing of sharks in Costa Rica! Comment with a 🦈 once you've signed and sent the petition to your friends. 

Together, we can turn the tide. 

Photos by @shawnheinrichs 

#shark #ocean #makoshark #conservation #turningthetide #sharkweek #sharkweek2020

node.text:
Warning - graphic content. If this video breaks your heart too, sign the petition at the link in our bio to stop the killing of sharks in Costa Rica. ⁠
⁠
Costa Rica has more than 40 species of sharks, and almost half are in serious danger of extinction, including silky sharks and hammerhead sharks. Costa Rica, a country that prides itself on protecting its endangered marine wildlife, is doing an abysmal job of stemming the alarming decline of endangered shark species in its waters.⁠ 
⁠
Earlier this year, Costa Rica’s government essentially legalized the overfishing, and subsequent extinction, of endangered sharks. President @carlosalvq removed the ability of the Ministry of Environment to protect sharks, and shifted management responsibilities to the Institute of Fisheries and Aquaculture (INCOPESCA) – meaning they are no longer protected by Costa Rica’s Wildlife Conservation Law.⁠
⁠
Sign the petition at the link in our bio and share this post to help spread the word. Today, we are asking President Alvarado to immediately repeal his harmful executive decree and restore the Ministry of Environment’s authority to conserve and protect sharks.
⁠
Video by @Shawnheinrichs,  @Andy_Mann⁠, and @paulnicklen 
⁠
#sharks #sharkweek #hammerhead #marinelife #ocean #costarica #sharkweek2020 #turningthetide

node.text:
This #SharkWeek, take action and sign the #petition to stop the killing of endangered sharks in Costa Rica (link in bio).

Teeming with silvertip, silky, and thresher sharks, Cocos Island of Costa Rica has earned its title as the “Island of Sharks”. Hundreds of tourists pour in from around the world each year to see these incredible animals and the vibrant seascapes they patrol. As top predators, sharks serve a critical role in maintaining the balance of our ocean’s most vulnerable ecosystems.

However, despite their inherent value as a keystone species, even endangered hammerheads, whose numbers are plummeting across the globe at a staggering rate, are still fished and commercialized by Costa Rica’s national fishing administration. Sharks are essentially considered non-wildlife by the Costa Rica government. The management of their species falls under INCOPESCA (the Institute of Fisheries and Aquaculture) — paving the way for the extinction of these invaluable animals.

Join us through the link in our bio to urge President @Carlosalvq to place these endangered animals under the proper management of the Ministry of the Environment. Share this campaign, spread the word, and follow along as we explore more of the secret lives of sharks and the challenges they face at the hands of commercialized fishing.

Photos by @Andy_Mann 

#SharkWeek #Sharks #costarica #turningthetide

node.text:
Remoras are known for hitching rides on the backs and undersides of sharks, but it’s not a free ride! Both species benefit from their symbiotic relationship. The remoras eat parasites off the shark's skin which helps keep them clean and, in turn, the remoras are protected from predators and get a free meal!

Comment with a 🦈 if you’re ready to tag along for shark week - these remoras surely are!

Video by @PaulNicklen

#sharks #oceanconservation #sharkweek

node.text:
A school of spinner sharks traverses the coast of Florida. Spinner sharks are both fast and agile predators. They catch their meals in quick bursts of speed, propelling themselves out of the water and twirling in the air before reentering. There were dozens of people in the water within a few hundred yards of these sharks and they had no idea. And, of course, there was no conflict. During #SharkWeek, let's continue to change perceptions about these misunderstood predators who are vital to keeping our marine ecosystems healthy.⁠
⁠
Photo by @PaulNicklen⁠
⁠
#sharks #marinelife #conservation #oceanschool
